declarations.comments: An update functions returns a new model and a possibly empty command

declarations.comments:
ProgramState tracks the current state of the model, vnode and
dom element.

These are needed to advance the state in reaction to a Cmd message.
declarations.title: ProgramState

declarations.comments:
Program describes the Bonsai program.

It is passed around in a ReaderT and stores
callbacks and a ref to the pending commands.
Event callbacks append to the list of pending
commands, they will then be applied
in the main event loop.
declarations.title: Program

declarations.comments: Produces a simple task (not cancellable, ony emits the return values
declarations.title: simpleTask

declarations.comments: Creates an update result with empty command.

declarations.title: mapResult

declarations.comments:
Issue a command.

For pure commands, this will send the messages and request a redraw.
For (asynchronous) task commands, the task will be started.

This can be used to start tasks, e.g. to initialize the model
declarations.title: issueCommand

declarations.comments: Procudes a task that can emit multiple times
declarations.title: emittingTask

declarations.comments:
Emit helper for Tasks.

In an emitting task, use this function to emit messages.

declarations.title: EventDecoder

declarations.comments: The type for the global javascript document
declarations.title: Document

declarations.comments:
A Command represents messages that should be applied to the Bonsai model

A command is either Pure (the constructor Cmd)
or an asynchronous Task.  The pure command simply contains
the messages that will be emitted.
The asynchronous Task gets an emitter function
that it can use to emit messages at will.

There is currently no effectful synchronous command -
there used to be, but it did not turn out very useful
except in dumbed down examples.

There could be a helper function that expresses simple
effectful commands as Tasks though.

There used to be a helper type for TaskContext -> Aff but
for some reason it did not unify in user code.
So the recommendation is to produce the command,
not the function with complicated signature that goes
inside a TaskCmd.
declarations.title: Cmd

declarations.comments: Effect for public types
declarations.title: BONSAI

declarations.comments: Produces a pure command
declarations.title: pureCommand

declarations.comments: Produces an empty command.
declarations.title: emptyCommand

modules.name: Bonsai.DOM.Primitive
modules.comments:
Primitive DOM Helpers

This module is used from Bonsai.VirtualDom, so it can't depend on anything
except Bonsai.Types

Since the VirtualDom does most of the DOM handling,
only some functionality is needed in addition to that
(e.g. elementById, setting the focus, ...)

This module does not distinguish DOM nodes and elements.
If you need additional functionaliy, Element is just
a newtype on a foreign - just use it with a different DOM
module.

declarations.comments:
When using HTML and JS, there are two ways to specify parts of a DOM node. 1. Attributes — You can set things in HTML itself. So the `class` in `
` is called an *attribute*. 2. Properties — You can also set things in JS. So the `className` in `div.className = 'greeting'` is called a *property*. So the `class` attribute corresponds to the `className` property. At first glance, perhaps this distinction is defensible, but it gets much crazier. *There is not always a one-to-one mapping between attributes and properties!* Yes, that is a true fact. Sometimes an attribute exists, but there is no corresponding property. Sometimes changing an attribute does not change the underlying property. For example, as of this writing, the `webkit-playsinline` attribute can be used in HTML, but there is no corresponding property!
declarations.title: Property

declarations.comments:
Options for an event listener. If `stopPropagation` is true, it means the
event stops traveling through the DOM so it will not trigger any other event
listeners. If `preventDefault` is true, any built-in browser behavior related
to the event is prevented. For example, this is used with touch events when you
want to treat them as gestures of your own, not as scrolls.
declarations.title: Options

declarations.comments: Same as `on` but you can set a few options.
declarations.title: onWithOptions

declarations.comments: Create a custom event listener.
declarations.title: on

declarations.comments:
Everything is `False` by default.

    defaultOptions =
        { stopPropagation = False
        , preventDefault = False
        }
declarations.title: defaultOptions

modules.name: Bonsai.EventDecoder
modules.comments:
Event decoder utilities

 For maximum performance, event handlers attached to the
 virtual DOM should be comparable by object identity.
 For this, you have call on with a top level function
 event decoder.

 This module defines composable BrowserEvents and
 utility functions that use them.  For maximum performance,
 you should define your own toplevel helpers
 with a composed BrowserEvent of your choice.


 Example:

   -- convenient but not optimal for handlers that get used a lot
   onInput MyMsg
   -- good because will compare equal
   myMsgDecoder = (f2cmd pureCommand <<< map f <<< targetValueEvent)
   onInputMyMsg = on "input" myMsgDecoder

declarations.comments: Read the value of target element's checked property
declarations.title: targetCheckedEvent

declarations.comments: Read the value of the target input element
declarations.title: targetValueEvent

declarations.title: targetValuesEvent

When using HTML and JS, there are two ways to specify parts of a DOM node. 1. Attributes — You can set things in HTML itself. So the `class` in `
` is called an *attribute*. 2. Properties — You can also set things in JS. So the `className` in `div.className = 'greeting'` is called a *property*. So the `class` attribute corresponds to the `className` property. At first glance, perhaps this distinction is defensible, but it gets much crazier. *There is not always a one-to-one mapping between attributes and properties!* Yes, that is a true fact. Sometimes an attribute exists, but there is no corresponding property. Sometimes changing an attribute does not change the underlying property. For example, as of this writing, the `webkit-playsinline` attribute can be used in HTML, but there is no corresponding property!

Bonsai HTML Attribute Helpers

Mostly transcribed from Elm with omissions - only the most frequently used.

declarations.comments: Create a style fragment for the Element DSL

declarations.title: cls

declarations.comments: Set the elements class for CSS.  Also class_

declarations.comments: Set the element's ID. Also id
declarations.title: id_

declarations.comments: Set the element's ID. Also id_

declarations.title: typ

declarations.comments: Defines the type of a button, input, or ...
declarations.title: type_

declarations.title: value

declarations.comments:
Defines an initial value which will be displayed in an input when
it is added to the DOM. Unlike value, changing defaultValue after
the input has been added to the DOM has no effect.
declarations.title: defaultValue

declarations.comments: Indicates if a checkbox is checked.
declarations.title: checked

declarations.comments: Provide a hint to the user what can be entered in an input or textarea
declarations.title: placeholder

declarations.comments: defines which option will be selected on page load.
declarations.title: selected

declarations.comments:
Indicates if a form or input can have their values automatically
completed by the browser.
declarations.title: autocomplete

declarations.comments:
The element should be automaticall focused after the page loads.
For button, inpupt, keygen, select, and textarea.
declarations.title: autofocus

declarations.comments:
Indicates whether the user can interact with a button, fieldset, input,
keygen, optgroup, option select or textarea.
declarations.title: disabled

declarations.comments: Defines the minimum number of characters allowed in an input or textarea
declarations.title: minlength

declarations.comments: Defines the minimum number of characters allowed in an input or textarea
declarations.title: maxlength

declarations.comments:
Indicates whether multiple values can be entered in an input of
type email or file.  Can also indicate that you can select many options.
declarations.title: multiple

declarations.comments:
Name of the element.
Used by a server to identify the fields in the form submit.
declarations.title: name

declarations.comments: This indicates that a form should not be validated when submitted.
declarations.title: novalidate

declarations.comments: Defines a regular expression which an input will be validated against.
declarations.title: pattern

declarations.comments: Indicates whether an input or textarea can be edited.
declarations.title: readonly

declarations.comments:
Indicates wheter this element is required to be filled out.
For inpupt, select and textarea.
declarations.title: required

declarations.comments:
For input specifies the width of an input in characters.
For select the number of visible options in dropdown list
declarations.title: size

declarations.comments: The element ID described by this label.
declarations.title: for

declarations.comments:

object, output, progress, select or textarea
declarations.title: form

declarations.comments:
Maximum value for value allowed. For input of type number or date,
the max value must be a number or date. For input, meter and progress
declarations.title: max

declarations.comments:
Minimum value for value allowed. For input of type number or date,
the min value must be a number or date. For input, meter and progress
declarations.title: min

declarations.comments: Step size for an input.  Use step "any" to allow any floating point number.
declarations.title: step

declarations.comments: Number of columns in a textarea
declarations.title: cols

declarations.comments: Number of rows in a textarea
declarations.title: rows

declarations.comments:
Indicates whether the text should be wrapped in a textarea.
Possible values are 'soft' and 'hard'
declarations.title: wrap

declarations.comments: The URL of a linked resource, such as a, area, base, or link
declarations.title: href

declarations.comments:
Specify where the result of clicking an a, area, base or form
would appear.  _blank (new window or tab), _self (same frame, default),
_partent (parent frame), _top (full body of the window).
Also takes the name of any frame you created.  As if.
declarations.title: target

declarations.comments:
Indicates that clicking an a and area will download the resource,
and that the downloaded resource will have the given filename.
declarations.title: downloadAs

declarations.comments: Indicates that clicking an a or area will download the resource
declarations.title: download

declarations.comments: Defines the number of columns a cell should span.
declarations.title: colspan

declarations.comments: Defines the number of rows a cell should span.
declarations.title: rowspan

These helper functions are borrowed from Elm,
the actual DSL was "inspired" by Smolder.

declarations.comments: A section that contains only navigation links
declarations.title: nav

declarations.comments: Self-contained content that could exist independently.
declarations.title: article

declarations.comments:
Content that is loosely related to the page.

If it is removed, the remaining content still makes sense.
declarations.title: aside

declarations.comments: Html header
declarations.title: h1

declarations.comments: Html header
declarations.title: h2

declarations.comments: Html header
declarations.title: h3

declarations.comments: Html header
declarations.title: h4

declarations.comments: Html header
declarations.title: h5

declarations.comments: Html header
declarations.title: h6

declarations.comments: Header of a page or section.
declarations.title: header

declarations.comments: Footer of a page or section.
declarations.title: footer

declarations.comments: A section containing contact information.
declarations.title: address

declarations.comments:
Main or important content in the document.

There is only one main element in the document.
declarations.title: main_

declarations.comments:
Main or important content in the document.

There is only one main element in the document.
declarations.title: main

declarations.comments: The content should be displayed as a paragraph.
declarations.title: p

declarations.comments: A thematic break between paragraphs of a section or article or any longer content.
declarations.title: hr

declarations.comments: Indictes that its content is preformattet and the format must be preserved.
declarations.title: pre_

declarations.comments: Represents content that is quoted from another source
declarations.title: blockquote

declarations.comments: Ordered list of items (li)
declarations.title: ol

declarations.comments: Unordered list of items (li)
declarations.title: ul

declarations.comments: An item of an enumeration list.
declarations.title: li

declarations.comments: Definition List, a list of terms and their definitions
declarations.title: dl

declarations.comments: A term in a definitions list
declarations.title: dt

declarations.comments: A definition in a definition list
declarations.title: dd

declarations.comments: A figure illustrated as part of the document
declarations.title: figure

declarations.comments: Legend for a figure.
declarations.title: figcaption

declarations.comments: Generic container with no special meaning.  Also div.
declarations.title: div_

declarations.comments:
Generic container with no special meaning.

This clashes with a function from the prelude,
so either use div_ or "import Prelude hiding (div)"
declarations.title: div

declarations.comments: Represents a link to another resource.
declarations.title: a

declarations.comments: Represents emphasized text, like a stress accent.
declarations.title: em

declarations.comments: Represents especially important text.
declarations.title: strong

declarations.comments:
Represents a side comment e.g. text like a disclaimer
or copyright.
Not essential to comprehension of the document.
declarations.title: small

declarations.comments: Represents content that is no longer accurate or relevant.
declarations.title: s

declarations.comments: Represents the title of a work.
declarations.title: cite

declarations.comments: An inline quotation.
declarations.title: q

declarations.comments: A term whose definition is contained in its nearest ancestore.
declarations.title: dfn

declarations.comments: An abbreviation or acronym, the expansion can be given in the title attribute.
declarations.title: abbr

declarations.comments: A data and time value, the machine-readable representation can be give in the datetime attribute.
declarations.title: time

declarations.comments: Represents computer code.
declarations.title: code

declarations.comments: Represents a variable
declarations.title: var

declarations.comments: Represents output of a program or computer.
declarations.title: samp

declarations.comments: Represents user input, often from the keyboard.
declarations.title: kbd

declarations.comments: Subscript
declarations.title: sub

declarations.comments: Superscript
declarations.title: sup

declarations.comments:
Represents text in some alternate voice or mood.

Used with bootstrap et. al. for icons
declarations.title: i

declarations.comments:
Text to which attention should be drawn for utilarian purposes.

It's bold, the non-semantic strong
declarations.title: b

declarations.comments: Underline with no predefined semantics
declarations.title: u

declarations.comments: Text highlighted for reference purposes, i.e. for relevance in another context.
declarations.title: mark

declarations.comments: Ruby annotations, ???
declarations.title: ruby

declarations.comments: Ruby annotations, ???
declarations.title: rt

declarations.comments: Ruby annotations, ???
declarations.title: rp

declarations.comments: Content with bidirectional text formatting.
declarations.title: bdi

declarations.comments: Represents bidirectionality of its children in order to override the unicode bidirectional algorithm.
declarations.title: bdo

declarations.comments: Text with no specific meaning.
declarations.title: span

declarations.comments: Line break.
declarations.title: br

declarations.comments: Line break opportunity
declarations.title: wbr

declarations.comments: Defines an addition to the document.
declarations.title: ins

declarations.comments: Defines a deletion from the document.
declarations.title: del

declarations.comments: An image (URL given by src attribute)
declarations.title: img

declarations.comments: Embedded HTML document
declarations.title: iframe

declarations.comments: Integration point for external application or content.
declarations.title: embed

declarations.comments: Represents external resource that may be processed by a plugin
declarations.title: object

declarations.comments: Parameters for plugins invoked by object.
declarations.title: param

declarations.comments: Represents a video
declarations.title: video

declarations.comments: Represents a sound or audio stream.
declarations.title: audio

declarations.comments: Allows specification of alternative media resources for video or audio.
declarations.title: source

declarations.comments: Timed text tracks for audio or video content
declarations.title: track

declarations.comments: Bitmap area for graphics rendering.
declarations.title: canvas

declarations.comments: Mathematical formule
declarations.title: math

declarations.comments: HTML Table
declarations.title: table

declarations.comments: Caption for a table
declarations.title: caption

declarations.comments: Colgroup for a table
declarations.title: colgroup

declarations.comments: Represents a column of a table.
declarations.title: col

declarations.comments: Table body - contains the data rows
declarations.title: tbody

declarations.comments: Table header - contains headers rows explaining the data
declarations.title: thead

declarations.comments: Table footer
declarations.title: tfoot

declarations.comments: A table row
declarations.title: tr

declarations.comments: A cell in a a table row.
declarations.title: td

declarations.comments: A cell in a table header.
declarations.title: th

declarations.comments: A submittable form
declarations.title: form

declarations.comments: Represents a set of controls in (usually) a form
declarations.title: fieldset

declarations.comments: The caption for a fieldset.
declarations.title: legend

declarations.comments: The caption for a form control
declarations.title: label

declarations.comments: Typed data field allowing the user to edit the data.
declarations.title: input

declarations.comments: A button that can be clicked.
declarations.title: button

declarations.comments: Control that allows section among a set of options
declarations.title: select

declarations.comments: A predefined set of options for other controls.
declarations.title: datalist

declarations.comments: A set of options, logically grouped.
declarations.title: optgroup

declarations.comments: A option in a select tag, or a suggestion in a datalist
declarations.title: option

declarations.comments: A multiline text edit control.
declarations.title: textarea

declarations.comments: A key-pair generator control.
declarations.title: keygen

declarations.comments: Represents the result of a computation.
declarations.title: output

declarations.comments: Represents the completion progress of a task.
declarations.title: progress

declarations.comments: Represents a scalar measurement with a known range.
declarations.title: meter

declarations.comments: Represents a widget from which the user can obtaion additional input or controls.
declarations.title: details

declarations.comments: A summary for a given details.
declarations.title: summary

declarations.comments: A command the user can invoke.
declarations.title: menuitem

declarations.comments: A list of invokable commands
declarations.title: menu

declarations.comments:
When using HTML and JS, there are two ways to specify parts of a DOM node. 1. Attributes — You can set things in HTML itself. So the `class` in `
` is called an *attribute*. 2. Properties — You can also set things in JS. So the `className` in `div.className = 'greeting'` is called a *property*. So the `class` attribute corresponds to the `className` property. At first glance, perhaps this distinction is defensible, but it gets much crazier. *There is not always a one-to-one mapping between attributes and properties!* Yes, that is a true fact. Sometimes an attribute exists, but there is no corresponding property. Sometimes changing an attribute does not change the underlying property. For example, as of this writing, the `webkit-playsinline` attribute can be used in HTML, but there is no corresponding property!
declarations.title: Property

declarations.comments:
Options for an event listener. If `stopPropagation` is true, it means the
event stops traveling through the DOM so it will not trigger any other event
listeners. If `preventDefault` is true, any built-in browser behavior related
to the event is prevented. For example, this is used with touch events when you
want to treat them as gestures of your own, not as scrolls.
declarations.title: Options

declarations.comments: Same as `on` but you can set a few options.
declarations.title: onWithOptions

declarations.comments: Create a custom event listener.
declarations.title: on

modules.name: Bonsai.Html.Events
modules.comments:
Bonsai HTML Event helpers

These are convenience functions, if you use an event handler
A LOT, you should call on with a top level function.
See explanation in Bonsai.EventDecoder

declarations.comments: Event options: prevent default, stop propagation
declarations.title: preventDefaultStopPropagation

declarations.comments: Event listener property for the click event.
declarations.title: onClick

declarations.comments: Suboptimal helper for boolean (checkbox) input
declarations.title: onCheckedChange

declarations.comments: Suboptimal helper for the input event.
declarations.title: onInput

declarations.comments: Emit commands on enter key presses
declarations.title: onKeyEnter

declarations.comments: Emit commands on enter or escape key presses
declarations.title: onKeyEnterEscape

declarations.comments: Emit a command on form submit.
declarations.title: onSubmit

modules.name: Bonsai.Html.Internal
modules.comments:
Bonsai HTML Internal module.

Implements the HTML DSL.
Heavily inspired by Smolder.

children.comments: Add an attribute to element node
children.title: withAttribute

children.comments: Add a style to an element node
children.title: withStyle

declarations.comments: A style that will be collected for VD.style
declarations.title: Style

declarations.comments: Markup Functor for the DSL
declarations.title: MarkupF

declarations.comments: Create a custom attribute
declarations.title: attribute

declarations.comments: Create a string property.
declarations.title: stringProperty

declarations.comments: Create a boolean property.
declarations.title: booleanProperty

declarations.comments: Create a text node.
declarations.title: text

declarations.comments: Create a leaf element - will not have children
declarations.title: leaf

declarations.comments: Create an element with children.
declarations.title: parent

declarations.comments:
keyedElement renders to a VirtualDom keyedNode.
The DSL does not work here to give it attributes and/or styles
declarations.title: keyedElement

declarations.comments: Render the content DSL to a VirtualDom node.
declarations.title: render

declarations.comments: Render the content DSL to an Array of VirtualDom nodes.
declarations.title: render'

declarations.comments: Add an optional attribute (operator !?)
declarations.title: withOptionalAttribute

declarations.comments: Wrap a (already rendered?) VNode
declarations.title: vnode

modules.name: Bonsai.Types
modules.comments:
This module defines the central Bonsai types
that are used in the Core and VirtualDom modules.

declarations.comments: Effect for public types
declarations.title: BONSAI

declarations.comments:
A BrowserEvent is simply a decoded foreign

This is inherently composable - it's a full monad.
declarations.title: BrowserEvent

declarations.comments:
A Command represents messages that should be applied to the Bonsai model

A command is either Pure (the constructor Cmd)
or an asynchronous Task.  The pure command simply contains
the messages that will be emitted.
The asynchronous Task gets an emitter function
that it can use to emit messages at will.

There is currently no effectful synchronous command -
there used to be, but it did not turn out very useful
except in dumbed down examples.

There could be a helper function that expresses simple
effectful commands as Tasks though.

There used to be a helper type for TaskContext -> Aff but
for some reason it did not unify in user code.
So the recommendation is to produce the command,
not the function with complicated signature that goes
inside a TaskCmd.
declarations.title: Cmd

declarations.comments:
And finally, a Command Decoder turns a foreign into a command

The CmdDecoder will be implemented using EventDecoders internally.
declarations.title: CmdDecoder

declarations.comments: The type for the global javascript document
declarations.title: Document

declarations.comments:
Emitters will get the Cmd into the Bonsai event loop.

The javascript side has little knowlege about
the internal structure of the purescript types,
so an emitting function is provided that takes
care of all that.

On error, the emitter returns true to signal to javascript
that the originating event should be logged to the console.
declarations.title: Emitter

declarations.comments: A EventDecoder decodes a foreign to a BrowserEvent
declarations.title: EventDecoder

declarations.comments:
The Task Context holds the emitter function for the task

Maybe: a way to get at the current model?
That would mean the model has to encoded in all the view functions
as well.  Maybe not a good idea.
declarations.title: TaskContext

declarations.comments: The type for the global javascript window
declarations.title: Window

declarations.comments: Helper to turn an F into emittable (Either Error Cmd)
declarations.title: f2cmd

declarations.comments: Produces an empty command.
declarations.title: emptyCommand

declarations.comments: Produces a pure command
declarations.title: pureCommand

modules.name: Bonsai.VirtualDom
modules.comments: Purescript interface to Elm Virtual DOM

declarations.comments:
An immutable chunk of data representing a DOM node. This can be HTML or SVG.

It's a functor that maps the Cmds that are emitted by event handlers.
declarations.title: VNode

declarations.comments:
When using HTML and JS, there are two ways to specify parts of a DOM node. 1. Attributes — You can set things in HTML itself. So the `class` in `
` is called an *attribute*. 2. Properties — You can also set things in JS. So the `className` in `div.className = 'greeting'` is called a *property*. So the `class` attribute corresponds to the `className` property. At first glance, perhaps this distinction is defensible, but it gets much crazier. *There is not always a one-to-one mapping between attributes and properties!* Yes, that is a true fact. Sometimes an attribute exists, but there is no corresponding property. Sometimes changing an attribute does not change the underlying property. For example, as of this writing, the `webkit-playsinline` attribute can be used in HTML, but there is no corresponding property!
declarations.title: Property

declarations.comments:
Options for an event listener. If `stopPropagation` is true, it means the
event stops traveling through the DOM so it will not trigger any other event
listeners. If `preventDefault` is true, any built-in browser behavior related
to the event is prevented. For example, this is used with touch events when you
want to treat them as gestures of your own, not as scrolls.
declarations.title: Options

declarations.comments: A Patch for efficient updates.
declarations.title: Patch

declarations.comments:
Create a DOM node with a tag name, a list of HTML properties that can
include styles and event listeners, a list of CSS properties like `color`, and
a list of child nodes.
declarations.title: node

declarations.comments:
Just put plain text in the DOM. It will escape the string so that it appears
exactly as you specify.

   text "Hello World!"
declarations.title: text

declarations.comments:
Create arbitrary *properties*.

   import JavaScript.Encode as Json

   greeting : Html
   greeting =
       node "div" [ property "className" (Json.string "greeting") ] [
         text "Hello!"
       ]

Notice that you must give the *property* name, so we use `className` as it
would be in JavaScript, not `class` as it would appear in HTML.
declarations.title: property

declarations.comments:
Create arbitrary HTML *attributes*. Maps onto JavaScript’s `setAttribute`
function under the hood.

Notice that you must give the *attribute* name, so we use `class` as it would
be in HTML, not `className` as it would appear in JS.
declarations.title: attribute

declarations.comments:
Would you believe that there is another way to do this?! This corresponds
to JavaScript's `setAttributeNS` function under the hood. It is doing pretty
much the same thing as `attribute` but you are able to have "namespaced"
attributes. This is used in some SVG stuff at least.
declarations.title: attributeNS

declarations.comments: Specify a list of styles.
declarations.title: style

declarations.comments: Create a custom event listener.
declarations.title: on

declarations.comments: Same as `on` but you can set a few options.
declarations.title: onWithOptions

declarations.comments:
Everything is `False` by default.

    defaultOptions =
        { stopPropagation = False
        , preventDefault = False
        }
declarations.title: defaultOptions

declarations.comments:
A performance optimization that delays the building of virtual DOM nodes.

Calling `(view model)` will definitely build some virtual DOM, perhaps a lot of
it. Calling `(lazy view model)` delays the call until later. During diffing, we
can check to see if `model` is referentially equal to the previous value used,
and if so, we just stop. No need to build up the tree structure and diff it,
we know if the input to `view` is the same, the output must be the same!
declarations.title: lazy

declarations.comments: Same as `lazy` but checks on two arguments.
declarations.title: lazy2

declarations.comments: Same as `lazy` but checks on three arguments.
declarations.title: lazy3

declarations.comments:
Works just like `node`, but you add a unique identifier to each child
node. You want this when you have a list of nodes that is changing: adding
nodes, removing nodes, etc. In these cases, the unique identifiers help make
the DOM modifications more efficient.
declarations.title: keyedNode

declarations.comments:
Render a virtual dom node to a DOM Element.

Initial step - the whole point in a VDom is the diffing
and patching.  So after rendering once, diff and applyPatches
should be used.
declarations.title: render

declarations.comments: Compute a patch between the old vnode representation and the new one.
declarations.title: diff

declarations.comments:
Apply a diff between VDoms to the DOM element.

The DOM element should be the one from the last
diff/applyPatches pass, or the initially rendered one.
declarations.title: applyPatches
